problems.title: Cyclic Merging
problems.statementHtml:
You are given nn non-negative integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an arranged on a ring. For each 1≤i<n1≤i<n, aiai and ai+1ai+1 are adjacent; a1a1 and anan are adjacent.

You need to perform the following operation exactly n−1n−1 times:

Note that this operation will decrease the size of the ring by 11 and update the adjacent relationships accordingly.

Please calculate the minimum total cost to merge the ring into one element.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105).

The following line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤1090≤ai≤109).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, please print a single integer — the minimum total cost.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, we can achieve a cost of 66 on [1,1,3,2][1,1,3,2] as follows:

  • Merge indexes 11 and 22 with a cost of 11, the ring becomes [1,3,2][1,3,2].
  • Merge indexes 11 and 33 with a cost of 22, the ring becomes [3,2][3,2].
  • Merge indexes 11 and 22 with a cost of 33, the ring becomes [3][3].

The total cost is 1+2+3=61+2+3=6. It can be proven that it is impossible to achieve a lower cost; thus, the answer is indeed 66.

In the second test case, the only option is to merge the two elements, with a cost of 22.

problems.title: Marble Council
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a multiset aa, which consists of nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an. You would like to generate a new multiset ss through the following procedure:

Please count the number of different multisets ss that can be generated through the procedure, modulo 998244353998244353.

Please note that the number of different multisets is counted, which means that the order of elements does not matter. However, the count of each element does matter, i.e. {1,1,2},{1,2},{1,1,2,2}{1,1,2},{1,2},{1,1,2,2} are all considered different.

∗∗The mode of a multiset is defined as the element which appears the most; if several elements are tied as the maximum, then all of them are considered modes.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤50001≤t≤5000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤50001≤n≤5000) — the size of multiset aa.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 50005000.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print one line containing a single integer — the number of different multisets you can obtain, modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, any non-empty subset of {1,2,3}{1,2,3} can be achieved, for a total of 77 multisets.

In the third test case, we can generate 44 different multisets:

  • Partition the elements into set {1,2,2}{1,2,2}, resulting in multiset {2}{2}.
  • Partition the elements into sets {1,2},{2}{1,2},{2}, resulting in multiset {2,2}{2,2}.
  • Partition the elements into sets {1},{2,2}{1},{2,2}, resulting in multiset {1,2}{1,2}.
  • Partition the elements into sets {1},{2},{2}{1},{2},{2}, resulting in multiset {1,2,2}{1,2,2}.

It can be proven that no other multisets are possible.

problems.title: Binary Wine
problems.statementHtml:
You are given nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an within the range [0,230)[0,230).

You can spend 11 coin to increase any aiai by 11. You can perform this operation any number of times.

You need to solve qq queries; for each query, you are given an integer cc, also in the range [0,230)[0,230). You would like it if there exists a sequence bb of length nn with the following properties:

Please calculate the minimum number of coins you will have to spend, such that there exists a suitable bb.

The queries are independent, meaning that any operations you perform on the sequence aa will not impact future queries.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case consists of two integers n,qn,q (1≤n≤5⋅1051≤n≤5⋅105, 1≤q≤5⋅1041≤q≤5⋅104) — the length of sequence aa and the number of queries.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai<2300≤ai<230) — the initial sequence aa.

Each of the next qq lines contains a single integer cc (0≤c<2300≤c<230) — the target XOR.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 5⋅1055⋅105.

It is guaranteed that the sum of qq over all test cases does not exceed 5⋅1045⋅104.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each query, output a single integer — the minimum coins you will have to spend, such that there exists a suitable bb.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, we spend 11 coin to increase a2a2 by 11, resulting in sequence [5,8][5,8]. A suitable bb would be [1,8][1,8]. It can be shown one cannot spend less than 11 coin to achieve the objective.

In the second test case, we can spend 77 coins to increase a1a1 by 77, resulting in sequence [16,9,8][16,9,8]. A suitable bb would be [16,9,1][16,9,1].

problems.title: Path Split
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a sequence of nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an.

You would like to partition aa into several subsequences∗∗ b1,b2,…,bkb1,b2,…,bk, satisfying the following conditions:

Please calculate the minimum number of subsequences you can partition aa into.

∗∗A sequence bibi is a subsequence of a sequence aa if bibi can be obtained from aa by the deletion of several (possibly, zero or all) element from arbitrary positions.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤1061≤n≤106) — the length of the sequence aa.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤2n1≤ai≤2n) — the sequence aa.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 106106.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print a single integer on one line — the minimum number of subsequences aa can be partitioned into.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, we can partition aa into subsequences [1][1]. It is obvious that we cannot partition aa into fewer subsequences; thus, 11 is the answer.

In the third test case, we can partition aa into subsequences [11,10,11,10],[13],[11],[11],[13][11,10,11,10],[13],[11],[11],[13]. Please note that [11,10,11,11,11,10][11,10,11,11,11,10] is not a valid sequence, since |11−11|=0≠1|11−11|=0≠1.

problems.title: Rainbow Branch
problems.statementHtml:
Given a tree with nn vertices, you need to assign a color to each edge. Define the inconvenience of an assignment as the maximum number of colors on the path between any two vertices.

You need to assign exactly kk different colors (each color must appear at least once) to the edges while minimizing the inconvenience of the assignment.

Please calculate the minimum inconvenience for all k=1,2,…,n−1k=1,2,…,n−1.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of the input contains one positive integer nn (3≤n≤3⋅1053≤n≤3⋅105) — the number of vertices.

The next n−1n−1 lines each contain two positive integers ui,viui,vi (1≤ui,vi≤n1≤ui,vi≤n) — indicating that there is an edge between vertices uiui and vivi.

It is guaranteed that the edges in the input form a tree.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 3⋅1053⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print a single line containing n−1n−1 integers. The ii-th integer represents the minimum inconvenience for k=ik=i.
problems.noteHtml: In the first test case, possible solutions for k=1,2,…,n−1k=1,2,…,n−1 are as follows:

problems.title: Arctic Acquisition
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a permutation∗∗ a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an of length nn.

An interval [l,r][l,r] (1≤l≤r≤n1≤l≤r≤n) is jagged if and only if it contains a 21435-subsequence; that is, there exist integers i1,i2,i3,i4,i5i1,i2,i3,i4,i5 such that l≤i1<i2<i3<i4<i5≤rl≤i1<i2<i3<i4<i5≤r, and ai2<ai1<ai4<ai3<ai5ai2<ai1<ai4<ai3<ai5.

Your task is to calculate how many of the n(n+1)2n(n+1)2 intervals are jagged.

∗∗A permutation of length nn is an array consisting of nn distinct integers from 11 to nn in arbitrary order. For example, [2,3,1,5,4][2,3,1,5,4] is a permutation, but [1,2,2][1,2,2] is not a permutation (22 appears twice in the array), and [1,3,4][1,3,4] is also not a permutation (n=3n=3 but there is 44 in the array).
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤1061≤n≤106) — the length of the permutation.

The second line of each test case contains nn distinct integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 106106.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the number of jagged subarrays.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the only jagged subarray is [1,5][1,5], containing [2,1,4,3,5][2,1,4,3,5] as a subsequence.

In the third test case, the subarray [1,8][1,8] is jagged because it contains [9,6,11,10,13][9,6,11,10,13] as a subsequence, which is a 21435-subsequence.

tutorial.contentHtml:
2166A — Same Difference

idea & solution: le0n

Tutorial

It can be observed that snsn will not change throughout the operations, therefore, for the final string to have every character the same, every character must be equal to snsn.

To change every character to snsn, we can iterate over all characters from right to left, repeatedly setting si−1←sisi−1←si if si−1≠snsi−1≠sn. Through this, we can need one operation for every character not equal to snsn, which is also obvious as a lower bound.

Time complexity: O(n)O(n).
